awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sizing Up the Smoke--Evaluating and Improving Our Ability to Predict Aged Wildfire Aerosol Size Distributions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is focused on studying the aging of emissions from biomass burning. Small particles emitted from biomass combustion can react in the atmosphere, changing their size, number, and composition. These aging processes will be modeled and the model results will be tested against actual data from field campaigns.

The following questions will be investigated: (1) What are the chemical processes that, when combined with the dispersion and coagulation of biomass-burning emissions, capture the evolution of aerosol size and number concentrations seen in the laboratory and the field? (2) Are the secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation rates and size-distribution changes measured in lab experiments consistent with the field measurements of aerosol aging? If they are not, can we determine why (e.g. lack of continuous dilution or wall losses in chamber experiments)? (3) What properties most strongly determine the aged biomass-burning aerosol size and number? E.g. total mass emission flux, fresh particle size, fuel type, modified combustion efficiency, wind speed, fire area, vertical mixing depth, sunlight. (4) Can the variability in aged biomass-burning aerosol size and number be captured by a simple parameterization that is a function of the most important of the above properties?
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Complex photochemistry and coagulation within biomass-burning plumes causes large changes in the aerosol size distribution in the first few hours after emission.  Understanding and simulating these changes is critical to understanding the impact of fires on air quality and climate. Previous plume-scale model studies have either focused on total aerosol mass rather than number and size or neglected the potential condensational growth of the particles in the plume. This project overcame these limitations by coupling a detailed model of the chemistry and aerosol dynamics of biomass-burning smoke to a large-eddy simulation model and used the combined model to investigate the evolution of aerosol number and size in smoke plumes.

We estimated the impact of sub-grid in-plume coagulation on the global aerosol size distributions and smoke radiative forcing. We implemented an in-plume coagulation scheme of into the GEOS-Chem-TOMAS global aerosol microphysics model. In-plume coagulation creates fewer but larger smoke particles. We showed that this in-plume coagulation reduces the magnitude of the cloud-albedo aerosol indirect effect of smoke aerosol but slightly increases the direct effect from smoke.

We prepared a systematic review of OA aging measured by previous field and laboratory campaigns We compared the changes in OA mass with age measured across campaigns as well as the change in OA oxidation. In the manuscript, we present hypotheses for differences and make recommendations for future analyses.

We investigated how fire size and background aerosol concentrations influence the smoke particle size distribution, mass, CCN, and extinction. This was a theoretical study and we are poised to use field observations to test our findings in this work as a next step. We find that fire size and background aerosol concentrations may greatly influence particle evolution, yet these parameters have generally not been considered when analyzing field data.

The results of this research will improve the accuracy of studies of the climate impacts of biomass-burning smoke. The modeling tools developed and tested as part of this research will reduce the uncertainty in the number of CCN from biomass burning and thus the indirect effect of biomass-burning aerosol.

At CSU, this project provided training two graduate students and an early-career research scientist. At AER, the project supported two early-career scientists. Results were communicated through journal articles and conference presentations.
